page.title: Adpositional Phrases - Other Complements
page.introduction: In addition, some prepositions or postpositions can stand alone without a complement due to particle movement, such as in the sentences Come [right in] and John turned the light [on/off]. Also, some languages allow prepositions or postpositions to be stranded when its complement is fronted with questions, as in Who(m) did you give the book [to _ ]?

form.introduction: Most languages will allow locative adverbs as complements of prepositions or postpositions, such as over there and in here.

form.introduction: Locative prepositions and postpositions are a special group in that they can take another locative PP as their complement. English examples of this type include: up [to the top], around [behind the shed] and over [by the table].

form.instruction: The rule allowing the PP complements is restricted to only locative prepositions or postpositions. Therefore, in the lexicon, you need to add the feature locative to all the prepositions postpositions prepositions and postpositions which can take a locative PP complement.

Since your language has only clitic prepositions, postpositions, prepositions and postpositions, if two locative prepositions postpositions prepositions or postpositions attach, it will still come out as a single locative PP (or locative AdvP if the head is an adverb).
form.introduction:
Temporals such as before and after are prepositions or postpositions when they take a nominal phrase complement, as in before you or after that. They can also have a gerund complement, as in before [signing the contract] and after [buying our new house], since gerunds are a special type of nominal phrase.
These same words can also have full sentences as their complements, as in before [the rain stops] and after [John came home]. In this usage, they are temporal adverbs instead of prepositions or postpositions, and the whole phrase is an adverbial clause which normally modifies the main sentence. Such examples will be handled in
Adverbial Clauses.
